pullRequest.body:
- Define Chomsky normal form grammars
- Add language-preserving translation between context-free grammars and Chomsky normal form grammars

Co-authored-by: Martin Dvorak martin.dvorak@matfyz.cz 

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:



If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: messageFile.md

Thanks, @YaelDillies, for the reviews.

At the same time, I'll note that internal reviewer discussion proposed that this is out of scope for Mathlib, with insufficient maintainer/reviewer expertise. (Note it's not just reviewing the material initially, but being confident we have expertise if this need repairing or refactoring in a few years.) No definitive answer was reached, and Yael's review may push things in a different direction. But I thought it good to be up front about the discussion.
My opinion is that the current PR is too big and has some style issues, but that if I review it could become mergeable and you might learn something ðŸ˜„

Thank you @YaelDillies!
It's my first time working with Lean and the PR is a building block (although much larger than the actual proof) for proving the Pumping Lemma for CFG, which i have already finished [here](https://github.com/AlexLoitzl/pumping_cfg).

Regarding the size, I could not think of a reasonable splitting of the PR, since I thought it was nonsensical to split it into multiple PRs which do some translation of CFG with no clear goal.

If in fact this will not get merged, I can try to carry out the proof of the pumping lemma directly on CFGs instead. Anyways, it would be nice to at least know that there is a prospect of this being merged before I pour more effort into it.

Being merged or not being merged I think is not greatly relevant. We are at a pivotal period of mathlib where we're hitting the limits of the monorepo model. Instead of accepting everything blindly in the `mathlib4` repo, we are now considering the possibility of having several mathlib repos, a central one (this one) along with one for each "mathematical dead end", namely one for each subdomain whose results are unlikely to ever be used in another domain. Eg here we could have the repo `mathlib-formal-language`. See https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/287929-mathlib4/topic/Repository.20for.20combinatorial.20games for more information.

Long story short, I think it's worth reviewing anyway.

messageFile.md
Can you resolve the conversations which you've dealt with, and leave unresolved the ones to which you think I might want to add something?
Could you please act on the comments below everywhere they apply (ie not just where I've commented)?
indent four spaces please

Since `Iff` is a structure
```suggestion
      u = p ++ [Symbol.nonterminal r.input] ++ q âˆ§ v = p ++ r.output ++ q where
  mp := Rewrites.exists_parts
  mpr := by rintro âŸ¨p, q, rfl, rflâŸ©; apply rewrites_of_exists_parts
```
I want a second opinion. I have never written `mp` and `mpr` explicitly in my life.

Is this true in general, or only if the terms can be stated concisely, in particular, should I structure a long proof as
````
lemma ... where
mp := by ...
mpr := by ...
````
vs.,
```
lemma ... := by
constructor
Â· ...
Â· ...
I would say if the terms can be stated concisely, you should do it. Otherwise, it's up to you

```suggestion
  induction p with
  | nil => cases r <;> constructor
  | cons _ _ hr => exact .cons r _ hr
```

```suggestion
lemma Rewrites.of_exists_parts (r : ChomskyNormalFormRule T N) (p q : List (Symbol T N)) :
```
for anonymous dot notation

I either don't understand why this should change or how to use it properly. If I change it as suggested, I need to spell out the entire Lemma whenever I want to use it as there is no parameter of type `Rewrites`. Hence, instead of writing `r.rewrites_of_exists_parts`, I now find myself writing `ChomskyNormalFormRule.Rewrites.of_exists_parts`. I picked the name similar to the same lemma `rewrites_of_exists_parts` of ContextFreeGrammar.
You mustn't have encountered anonymous dot notation yet. Wherever you have a goal of the form `âŠ¢ Rewrites _ _ _`, you can now do `exact .of_exists_parts _ _ _ _`

Nice, thank you!
I have seen it, but tried using it with `apply .of_exists_parts` and thought I am missing something
Ah yes, `apply` doesn't elaborate using the expected type, so can't use anonymous dot notation. I advise you to use `refine` instead

```suggestion
/-- Add extra prefix to CNF rewriting. -/
```

It's good style to not spend too many lines moving data around when it is done in a straightforward way
```suggestion
      refine âŸ¨x, y, mâ‚ + 1, mâ‚‚, hw, Produces.trans_derivesIn âŸ¨r, hrg, ?_âŸ© hdâ‚, hdâ‚‚, by omegaâŸ©
      rw [hp, â† List.singleton_append, â† List.append_assoc]
      apply r.rewrites_of_exists_parts
```
I tried my best... I am mostly struggling if rewrites/intros are involved, where I don't know if/how I can avoid breaking things apart.

As general rule of thumb:
* `use` and `constructor` can always be combined into a `refine`
* `exact` and `constructor` can always be combined into a `refine`
* `apply` leads to weak unification and I encourage you to use `refine` instead

```suggestion
      exact .inr âŸ¨nâ‚, nâ‚‚, u', huu â–¸ rflâŸ©
```

```suggestion
  refine .append_right (.append_left ?_ _) _
```
If `append_right`/`append_left` had one less explicit argument, you could even write
```suggestion
  refine .append_right <| .append_left ?_
```
Regarding the second comment, it's probably best to keep it consistent with the corresponding definition for context-free grammars?

> it's probably best to keep it consistent with the corresponding definition for context-free grammars?

Given that the context-free grammar API hasn't been battle-tested, I would say consistency is fine to break here. The better option would be to fix the corresponding context-free grammar definition
You want to change a lemma, not a definition, right?
Yes, it's a lemma
I am not a fan of arguments being inferred from the output, but I will accept this change for `ContextFreeGrammar.{Produces|Derives}.append_{left|right}` itself.

There's nothing called `terminals` here. Did you mean
```suggestion
lemma projectString_terminal {u : List T} :
    projectString (u.map (@Symbol.terminal T (N âŠ• T))) = u.map Symbol.terminal := by
```

```suggestion
  | .terminal t => .terminal t
  | .nonterminal n => .nonterminal (.inl n)
```
Here and everywhere else

Regarding the multiple comments about anonymous dot notation. Is there any reason not to use it, e.g. for clarity?
Otw I'll go though everything changing it whenever possible.

You can always hover over an anonymous dot notation use to see what it really refers to, and my personal philosophy is that clarity is *gained* when you use anonymous dot notation, because it signals "This is just the obvious constructor"

```suggestion
def embedSymbol : Symbol T N â†’ Symbol T (N âŠ• T)
```
Here and everywhere else

```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma embedSymbol_nonterminal (nt : N) :
    embedSymbol (Symbol.nonterminal nt) = (@Symbol.nonterminal T (N âŠ• T)) (Sum.inl nt) := by
  rfl
```

You can do
```suggestion
lemma projectString_terminals {u : List T} :
    projectString (u.map .terminal : List (Symbol T (N âŠ• T))) = u.map Symbol.terminal := by
```
which is arguably more readable

Make it a list maybe?
```suggestion
* `ContextFreeGrammar.eliminateEmpty` removing rules with an empty right-hand side,
* `ContextFreeGrammar.eliminateUnitRules` removing rules with a single nonterminal right-hand side,
* `ContextFreeGrammar.restrictTerminals` restricting all terminals to only occur as the single
  symbol of a rule's right-hand side, and
* `ContextFreeGrammar.restrictLength` translating `ContextFreeRule`s with multiple nonterminals to
  `ChomskyNormalFormRule`s with only two nonterminals on the right-hand side.
```

```suggestion
nonrec theorem Derives.head_induction_on {v : List (Symbol T g.NT)} {P : âˆ€ u, g.Derives u v â†’ Prop}
    {u : List (Symbol T g.NT)} (huv : g.Derives u v)
    (refl : P v (Derives.refl v))
    (head : âˆ€ {u w} (huw : g.Produces u w) (hwv : g.Derives w v), P w hwv â†’ P u (hwv.head huw)) :
    P u huv :=
  huv.head_induction_on refl head
```
I did this only here as I could not find a good explanation of the exact meaning  - or a definite answer on when to use it.

`nonrec theorem foo`:= ...` means that `foo` is nonrecursive, so if you use something called `foo` inside the `...` Lean will know that it must be referring to something else than the thing you're proving. Here, `nonrec` lets Lean know that `.head_induction_on` doesn't refer to `Derives.head_induction_on`, so it must refer to `Relation.ReflTransGen.head_induction_on`

Do you want to make these headers?
```suggestion
/-! ### Alternative definition of `ContextFreeGrammar.Derives` which allows to use well-founded
induction on derivations, by explicitely counting the number of steps of the transformation -/
```

```suggestion
  | tail _ last ih => exact ih.trans_produces last.append_left
```
and below

```suggestion
    (hnu : g.Produces [.nonterminal n] u) :
```

```suggestion
lemma derives_iff_exists_derivesIn {g : ContextFreeGrammar.{uN} T}
    {v w : List (Symbol T g.NT)} :
```

No point duplicating the `Derives` API
```suggestion
```

I'd suggest
```suggestion
  | zero {w : List (Symbol T g.NT)} : g.DerivesIn w w 0
  /-- n + 1 steps, if transforms `u` to `v` in n steps, and `v` to `w` in 1 step  -/
  | succ {u v w : List (Symbol T g.NT)} {n : â„•} :
    g.DerivesIn u v n â†’ g.Produces v w â†’ g.DerivesIn u w n.succ
```

```suggestion
    g.Derives v w â†” âˆƒ n : â„•, g.DerivesIn v w n where
  mp hgvw := by
```

... then
```suggestion
```

```suggestion
lemma Produces.derivesIn_one {v w : List (Symbol T g.NT)} (hvw : g.Produces v w) :
```

```suggestion
    g.DerivesIn v w 1 := .succ .zero hvw
```
Can you make this a separate PR? I think it's close to completion.

pullRequest.title: feat(Computability): Add Chomsky Normal Form Grammar and translation
